label: Relatable “AI” / remembering it’s a semi-steerable text machine
synthesis: I keep noticing the gap between how most people experience LLMs—like a conversational AI—and how I experience them as a semi-predictable function that turns input text into output text. I want to stay honest about the mechanics without losing the practical magic that makes them useful as a mirror, a coder, and a tool.
quote: I think many of the users just see them as "bots" or "AI" that can respond in a human-like way. But, you and I? We know they're a bit more mechanical than that.

label: I stopped “chatting with AI” and started thinking in primitives
synthesis: After a year of using LLMs for everything from summarization to extraction, I can feel myself shifting from using a tool to building with components. Naming generating, distilling, extracting, and eliciting as primitives makes it feel like architecture instead of vibes. It’s the difference between talking to a thing and designing with it.
quote: having used these things for the better part of a year now, as a low-cost therapist, as a coding assistant, as a text classification tool, as a summarization tool, as a data extraction tool (etc etc), I've gained an appreciation for what they can do, and I've come up with a series of "primitives" that I intend to use as sort of architecture building blocks

label: What if I treated an LLM as composable operations instead of a single assistant?
synthesis: I’m trying to see LLMs less as one assistant and more like a set of distinct capabilities—generate, combine, distill, style, extract, transform, elicit—that I can chain together. I’m poking at whether this lens makes outputs more controllable and systems more buildable, instead of hoping the chat vibe stays consistent.
quote: The point is that when we interact with LLMs via chat interfaces, we're often getting it to do some combination of all of these. It works well, most of the time, but it's not cleanly repeatable.

label: Open-prompt ecosystems: what happens when people can pop the hood together?
synthesis: I have this pet theory that open, tweakable platforms—where people can test, re-run, and exchange prompts—will create evolutionary pressure toward better prompts. I’m wondering if that openness would also reveal real user behavior and drive deeper engagement than closed, polished chat experiences.
quote: if we build platforms that let us do this in a way that users can pull open the hood and tweak, test, and re-run, share/exchange the prompts that we build with, we'll get way better engagement, way deeper insights into user behavior, and way better prompts (through democratic evolution that open platforms provide).

label: LLMs as language-crunching machines (calculator energy, not mysticism)
synthesis: Calling LLMs “machines for crunching language” keeps me honest about what’s happening: text in, text out, with a lot of mush in the middle. It’s my way of grounding the hype in something I can actually build on, like calculators crunching numbers.
quote: I've been thinking about LLMs as "machines for crunching language" for a while now. It's analogous to how calculators are "machines for crunching numbers."

label: AI as salvation story / AI as just another mechanism in the stack
synthesis: I can feel myself getting swept up in the AI hype—like it’s about to rewrite every part of life. But when I zoom out, it looks like language, numbers, and statistics all over again: powerful tools that still didn’t deliver the peace and harmony we keep promising ourselves. I’m stuck between awe at the potential and suspicion that we’re repeating an old story.
quote: It's fascinating technology. There seems to be a lot of potential. It seems like it's about to revolutionize everything everyone is doing at every level. If only. The reality I see is that it's just another mechanism.

label: Why do new tools never cash the “peace and harmony” check?
synthesis: We keep inventing new layers of abstraction—language, math, now AI—and each time we act like this will finally fix the human condition. And yet the same old promises of harmony stay out of reach, like the tool upgrades don’t touch whatever the real bottleneck is. I can’t stop asking what we’re missing that isn’t just more technology.
quote: These earlier tools similarly heralded untold changes and advancement into our lives. And yet... the underlying promises of peace and harmony seem to remain unfulfilled. Why is that?

label: The stitched-together illusion of clarity
synthesis: I’m realizing how much my sense of clarity is manufactured—my eyes and attention dart around, and my brain fills in the gaps like it’s all in focus. It’s unsettling to admit I’m not actually seeing it all; I’m getting a convincing composite. And once I see that, I start wondering how often my certainty about AI, work, or life is just the same kind of stitched-together illusion.
quote: In truth, your brain is just stitching together a mess of many little high-density puzzle pieces of the images, and hand-waving over the rest. In essence, it's lying to you, giving you the feeling and perception that everything is clear and you're seeing it all, all the time.

label: The two-balloon lesson: my intuition lies about “equalizing”
synthesis: The balloon experiment hits me because it violates the story my intuition wants to tell—of things naturally equalizing. Instead, the big balloon takes more and the small collapses, because the pressures don’t work the way my gut expects. It makes me suspicious of how many other “obvious” stories I’m walking around with that are just wrong.
quote: Two balloons of different volume are connected. Spoiler: Our intuition tells us that they should equalize, and the small balloon will grow, but that is wrong . The large balloon takes on even more of the small ballon's air, until their pressures are in equilibrium.

label: Autopilot “more” / the lived human experience getting swept into the torrent
synthesis: When I look at commerce and business, I see people chasing faster, better, more—like it’s self-evidently good—without asking what it does to the humans inside it. I can’t shake the image of us being carried along by momentum we didn’t choose, measuring progress in output while ignoring what it feels like to live it. The part that scares me is how normal that blindness has become.
quote: it often looks like we're just on autopilot, excitedly and blindly pursuing "more," without thinking about why more is even desirable. So many of these things just assume that better, faster, more is a desirable outcome, without considering the experience of the humans who are being ushered into that torrent.

label: What is the point of “more” if it isn’t in service of living?
synthesis: I keep coming back to the basic trade: we work, build, and extract resources so we can afford the experiences that make life feel worth it—meals with friends, snowboarding, a family. But the chain is long and expensive, and it’s easy to forget the point and start serving the machine instead of the life. I’m trying to name the “something worth seeing” before I lose it in the logistics.
quote: Why do we want to work more? Build more? Harvest more? Get more? Because something here is worth doing. Something here is worth seeing. Something here is worth experiencing.
